Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2009 06:03AM NatureGrrl wrote: I can't add to the excellent answers you've gotten except to add support and say it isn't surprising to me that you're tired -- even with reduced activity, a trip to Hawaii a month after surgery is really taxing to your body. (but it sounds lovely -- I'd go in a heartbeat!)  Give yourself time to rest and heal more, and keep your dr. informed... and take good and gentle care of yourself!  That's the hard part for me -- my head always wants my body to be further along than it is!  As I was reminded once (and it made me want to grind my teeth, but I saw the truth in it), we heal in (God's, the universe's, whatever you want to insert here) time, not ours.   In other words, be patient! (but do keep your dr. informed!).  Warm hug.
Posts.Title: Overwhelming fatigue 4 weeks after Mastectomy JenXX Olami

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2010 06:29AM NatureGrrl wrote: I think your questions have been addressed but thought I'd chime in with my own experience:  I had chemo, then a lumpectomy (would have been a mastectomy if I'd done surgery up front but by the time I got done with chemo they couldn't find any cancer, and all nodes were negative).  About 6 weeks after my surgery I started radiation. For what this is worth:  You won't have to stop living your normal life.  Radiation isn't nearly as devastating to the body as chemo. A lot of the fear we have and stories we hear about how awful radiation is are based on old treatment plans.  They used to do fewer but more intense treatments, which were harder on the body, and they also can target the areas being treated much better. I had some fatigue but nothing like chemo (which did significantly impact my life).  You may be tired, you may want to nap some or go to bed earlier, you may have some skin reaction (I had discoloration but no blistering or itching), but you will be able to live pretty much as always.  My diagnosis was also out of the blue and devastating, but since I've been a caregiver for others who have gone through cancer, I wasn't uncomfortable with the treatment options I was hearing (it helped a lot that I already knew and trusted my oncologist and his staff).  By all means, get other opinions and ask all you need to ask to be comfortable with whatever you chose.  And listen to your gut.  Best of luck and a warm hug.
Posts.Title: Recently Diagnosed and Concerned about Radiation hopie NatureGrrl

Posts.Content: May 22, 2010 07:08AM NatureGrrl wrote: Kymmber, I don't know about your program, but I didn't have health insurance when I was dx, either... but the women at the breast center told me about the local YW's breast cancer program, which helped pay for some of my initial costs, and then they put me onto the state's fast-track medicaid program for women with breast and cervical cancer.  I've always pulled my own weight so going on medicaid involved some pride-swallowing but it's been a godsend.  I believe this is a program every state has so if you're in the US you might want to check into it.  It pays for EVERYthing (at least for me it has) and prevented me from going thousands and thousands of dollars into debt.  You're in the right place for support and information, please do keep us posted, and good luck on Monday...
Posts.Title: Scared & Confused kymmber Lisa1962

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2010 05:58PM NatureGrrl wrote: Just a quick post, but I wanted to chime in:  it's commonly known that people (it may be women more than men but I'd have to find the studies again) who are caregivers come down with their own life-threatening illnesses at a significantly greater percentage than the general population.  I was caring for my mom, who had cancer and dementia, and was seriously stressed and overwhelmed when I found my own cancer (no other family history of cancer, and mom's and mine aren't related). I also went through a series of significant and mostly stressful changes in my life over the several years leading up to that.  I suspect, as is noted in some of the current books about cancer, that our bodies have the ability to naturally fight cancer most of the time, but various things -- stress being just one -- can weaken our immune systems and allow cancer to take hold.  Did stress cause my cancer? I have no way of knowing.  But I am making sure that I'm putting good changes into effect to help me more effectively cope with stress in the future, and making other changes that hopefully will keep me healthy as possible.
Posts.Title: Stress and Breast Cancer lukejessesmom texasrose361

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2010 08:42AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:55AM by NatureGrrl Melinda, you echo the thoughts and feelings of many of us.  You are not snippy and bitter.  You are strong, assertive, and willing to speak out!  I'm tired of bc being turned into something pink and fluffy, tired of it being trivialized, misunderstood, sexualized, and on and on. Not to mention the exploitation by so many companies.  So thank you. There are a number of anti-pink threads going right now, and as I've read them, I've wanted to copy and paste various comments into a document (names removed) and send it out to all the media who keep promoting pink, who just don't get it, and who never hear this side of things.   However, although I know our comments are considered public, I still regard them as being shared here within the context and support of the boards and so in my mind they're private.  Besides, I believe bc.org would have to clear that first anyway.  But most of all, I've never wanted to violate anyone in any way by copying without asking.  But I'm wondering... what if we cleared it with bc.org, and start a thread that at the top says, if you'd like to share comments on how you feel about Pinktober and the pinking of bc  that will be shared with the media, please post here... would that work for anyone?  We could compile for so many days, make sure everyone knew we wouldn't use names, locations, etc...  Does this sound like a remotely reasonable idea?  Any thoughts? I only suggest it because darn it, the world needs to hear us, not the Pink Promoters!  I've composed a couple of letters I'm sending out (one to the "bras across the river" promoters and one to our local paper) but my voice alone doesn't mean as much as many voices together.  Alone, I just feel like they'll read my letters and say I'm snippy and bitter :) or something like that... but having the support of many voices, they might realize the problems with Pinkober, etc. Lowrider, I posted a comment about National Metastatic BC Awareness day using your facts on my FB page... a small something, but something.

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2010 04:48AM NatureGrrl wrote: Leah, yes.  Those people are survivors.  lovemygarden, thank you for a laugh!

I will never shy away from telling people the truth about this disease.  They won't learn if I don't say something when they spout misconceptions. Oh, my, such a soapbox I'm on this month!
Posts.Title: My pink problem Melinda41 daffodil45

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2010 08:12AM - edited Feb 15, 2010 08:16AM by NatureGrrl I had my last Taxol (after A/C) Sept. 23.  My knees just quit hurting a few weeks ago.  I still have elbow joint pain but it's getting better.  Still have some neuropathy from the Taxol, but it's slooooowly getting better as well. My hair started growing back not long after I got off the A/C and grew all through Taxol. Now it often gets mistaken for a really short, modern haircut (I haven't had it trimmed yet but it won't be long before it needs it in at least a few places!).  I can't say when my eyebrows and lashes started looking more normal; they took awhile, but at 5 months out from my last chemo, they look pretty normal.  Including all those stray hairs I really should pluck :) I was told during radiation to expect pains etc. perhaps off and on for as long as a year out from treatment -- but that I should see steady improvement.  I have and am grateful.  I'm grateful for finally getting some energy back as well. Cancer sucks, chemo is really hard, but life is good. PS  I was surprised to have joint pain AFTER chemo but not so much during -- the NP told me that was because the steriods in my body were masking a lot of the pain, and that time would take care of it.  I don't know if that's right or not but I do know the pain is going away now.
Posts.Title: How long body aches last after Taxol pinkribbongirl pinkribbongirl

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2011 11:14PM NatureGrrl wrote: Never feel silly.  Until we go through it, we don't know what's normal and what isn't, and it's better to err on the side of caution.  I was told by my physician to call any time with any concern, and although I didn't often call after hours, I figured it was way better than either worrying or paying for a trip to the ER or urgent care if the latter weren't called for.  Or not following up on something that turned out to be a problem.  I'm glad it's all fine, and glad you got hold of your PS.  Now you can relax!
Posts.Title: Help - Bright Yellow Skin!!!!! A_pallens barbe1958

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2010 02:26PM - edited Feb 23, 2010 02:29PM by NatureGrrl I finished radiation about a month ago.  My skin is pretty much back to normal -- in fact, was pretty much back to normal after just a week or so of ending radiation.  My radiologist suggested using aloe vera gel (97% aloe vera or better, I also used Jason's brand, or she also recommended the "goo" directly from the plant) every night, so I did.  I also used shea butter on top of that and was told Aquaphor or even Vasoline would serve the same purpose -- to keep moisture in the skin.  Wash minimally and gently to avoid drying out and abrading the skin. The only caveat was to not apply anything to my skin for at least 3 hours before treatment because that could cause skin problems (intensify the radiation effects on the skin).  I followed all this every night religiously.  Oh, and I was told not to use any deoderant under the radiation arm for the duration, so I didn't. I had no burning, itching, blisters, etc.  My skin got pink quickly (faster than "normal," which had me worried) and towards the end, red, but that was it. I'm fair skinned but never burned easily, FWIW.  Was it the aloe vera and shea butter?  No way to know for sure, but it sure didn't hurt to use it. I had some fatigue from radiation but nothing like chemo. My rad. techs were good about getting me right in and out so my wait time was minimal.  Overall, it really was a breeze compared to anything and everything else I've been through.  Everyone is different, of course, but they really have changed treatment so much over how it used to be done and the majority will experience less SE's than used to be the case.  Hang in there!
Posts.Title: Predicting ones reaction to radiation 3monstmama NatureGrrl

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2010 07:09AM NatureGrrl wrote: I agree, you might want to talk to them again for clarification. I got a similar kind of talk as yours from one person before I started treatment, but when I saw the techs who gave me the treatments they all told me to do what I wanted, just try not to rub/scrub the marks.  I lathered my breast and underarm by hand. My marks came off no matter what I did (or didn't do), so I just re-drew them after my shower every night before they faded too much (the techs OK'd this -- not a daily problem, but over the weekend they would fade a lot). For some reason that ink didn't want to stick to my skin at all -- it started flaking off as soon as they drew it on and it dried.  Only other big caveat I got was to not put anything on my breast (lotion, oil) for (gosh darn chemo brain!) either 3 or 5 hours (I can't remember which!) before treatment, because that could exacerbate problems.  I used aloe and an oil-based product at night. I do have permanent tattoos now but they're just pin-point dots, 5 of them, and  even after I got those they used the sharpies. They potentially have to remark you every 5 treatments anyway (they'll probably check you to make sure you're lined up right).  And if you see them every day, they can touch up the marks if need be. So don't let them scare you about showering and the marks, etc. No reason not to exercise, either.  It will help!  Best of luck...
Posts.Title: Exercise MariannaLaFrance 3monstmama

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2010 10:13AM NatureGrrl wrote: I was terrified of SE's, too, and although there were some, they were all manageable and not nearly as bad as I thought they might be. When I had A/C, I had a small amount of nausea but never felt like I was going to throw up, and between meds and ginger that was easy to control.  I had no dizziness at all.  I was a bit hyper from the steroids but that lasted only a few days and once I knew what it was and expected it, it was OK.  My sleep patterns got all mixed up but that seemed minor to me, even though it meant I was tired. The worst thing I had was pain from the Neulasta shots, common with A/C, I ached so bad after the first one that I could barely stand to walk 1/2 a block, but the women on this forum mentioned trying generic Claritin (not Claritin D, just the plain Claritin) for that... my oncologist OK'd it and I'll be darned if I didn't have any pain from Neulasta after that.  Worth remembering if you'll have those shots.  I just took it nightly for the rest of my treatment (I have allergies anyway so it also helped with those).  Check with your oncologist to make sure it's ok with him/her. Take whatever you'll enjoy doing.  You can read, knit, listen to music, write, etc., just about anything you can do while sitting.  I also got up and walked around some, dragging my IV with me, but truthfully mostly I napped a lot and read some. Oh, yes, my hair started falling out exactly 14 days after my first A/C, I shaved my head to avoid the aches from that and also to get it over with (I thought seeing my hair come out daily would be too traumatic).  Everyone's different in how they approach that, though, so do what feels right for you. Drink lots of fluids to help flush things out and to stay well-hydrated.  Very important. Expect orange/pink urine after the A/C for a few hours :) I won't say A/C was easy or fun but it wasn't anywhere near as bad as all the stories I heard that had me terrified.  I was glad when it was over because I was so blasted tired but it was all manageable.  Important thing is to keep your oncologist informed about anything that doesn't feel right to you -- and to ask any questions you need to ask.   We're all here for you.  Best of luck and a warm hug.
Posts.Title: Scheduled to have Chemo Nov. 3rd ChrisinSD lorrhaw

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 11:07AM NatureGrrl wrote: No such thing as dumb questions!  I drove myself to and from all treatments, but I didn't have far to go (20 minutes). My oncologist was fine with it but always a good idea to ask him/her.   Some people have a back-up plan for the first treatment in case they're too tired after or just to see how they feel, or if you have very far to do you might want help. I didn't shave my own head -- your blood counts may be low and you probably don't want to risk nicking and infection.  If you have someone else do it, probably not a good idea to use a blade in any event.  Use an electric razor with a guard on it for the shortest cut (again, with no guard, you may risk nicking).  I went to a salon and had them do it (and they didn't charge me when they found out why I was doing it) but lots of people have an SO or friend do it.  Some people make it a party, even.   I was left with a very short fuzz which fell out over time.  I actually liked things about being bald -- low maintenance, for one, and I loved the way the wind felt on my scalp (I went everywhere bald).   But I was glad when my hair started growing back. Feel free to ask anything!
Posts.Title: Scheduled to have Chemo Nov. 3rd ChrisinSD lorrhaw

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 01:06PM NatureGrrl wrote: Timerdog... big hug.  As you've realized by now, we're all here for you.  Although I will say it was rough at times to go through treatment alone (and take care of my mom, who also had cancer, and dementia...), I read enough stories here to know it would have been even worse had I been with someone who wasn't supportive.  It's a terrible time for a relationship to fall apart -- but really, there are no good times.  I found an incredible amount of support here and it helped a lot.  I also had a therapist (at my onc. office) that I saw a lot, and although cancer support groups didn't work for me, they do for many people, so keep that as an option, too. Chemo can be hard (I respectfully disagree with the previous poster on this one) -- actually getting it wasn't hard, but dealing with the accumulation over time was; I had serious fatigue, mainly, but I can't say it was like the flu.  It was more overwhelming than that, but everyone is different, some do go through it easier than others. Youth is on your side on that count. If you're given steroids with/after chemo (I got them around every A/C treatment), that was the only time I found myself feeling impatient, but it only lasted for the time I was actually on steroids (I think it was 3 or 4 days each A/C, which was once every 3 weeks), and once I figured out what was going on, I expected it and could deal with it.  I wasn't taking care of a child but I was taking care of an elderly woman with dementia, and sometimes it felt like I was taking care of a child.  I guess all I'm trying to say is, although it at times was difficult, I did it, and you will too. It's not easy nor fun, and in an ideal world we'd all have someone to hug us at the end of the day and give us what we need, but you can do it. By the way, if he says "I'll see you through this but I can't say where I'll be a year from now," he's not going to see you through it, because it doesn't end the minute treatment is over; it's an ongoing process of healing and recovery.  Best of luck to you, and please do use the boards for support and understanding.
Posts.Title: relationship will not survive timerdog alamik

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2010 08:49AM NatureGrrl wrote: Just wanted to add my voice -- yes, surgery is frightening -- but getting a sedative beforehand is a good idea to calm yourself down. I always ask for one.   Once you get into the operating room, you go to sleep so fast and easily, and the next thing you know you're waking up and it's all over.  I had some mild nausea with surgery some years back but with more recent surgeries I haven't had any.  I think they're much better at regulating that.  In any event, they monitor you closely; and as you wake up, if you feel even a little nauseous, let them know and they'll give you something to knock it right down. For me, the anticipation is always worse than the actual event.  In the days leading up to the surgery, find things to do that help calm you, do things you enjoy, eat healthy, and get plenty of rest.  If you're nervous, vent!  It helps.  Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Risk of anesthesia -mastectomy Polyana mawhinney

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2010 06:19AM NatureGrrl wrote: As has been mentioned, everyone is different.  You've gotten lots of good suggestions.  No matter what, you'll be OK! My own experience was that  I had significant depression during and after chemo (AC, then Taxol), and went on anti-depressants for several months.  It's not uncommon but that doesn't mean it will be your path -- but if it is, as others have said, it's not permanent.  I'm not sure what part of it was treatment SE's and what part of it was just plain having cancer (while I was living with my mother and watching her die).  Too much going on for me to sort out the threads but to me it wasn't important where it was coming from, it was important for me to deal with it.  I had to accept what I was going through, whatever it was.  Denying that I was truely depressed (as I did at first) and stuffing it down and trying to put on a happy face just made me feel worse.  Another thing that really helped me was seeing a therapist who worked with cancer patients. The support I got through that was invaluable. The steroids knocked me for a loop because I didn't know about their SE's (hyper for a couple of days, and played havoc on my mood) but once I figured that out I was prepared and able to deal with it. Best of luck and a big hug!
Posts.Title: Will AC take away my happy face? Joanne58 amoccia53160

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 12:59PM NatureGrrl wrote: Choca, I got my pillow today, thank you so much -- I love it and it's the perfect size for nesting under my arm!  Thanks again....
Posts.Title: Heart-Shaped Pillows choca1711 SLL101984

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2010 06:44AM NatureGrrl wrote: Nats, I'm glad at least that part of your experience was positive, and kudos to the hospital for knowing what every hospital should know!  I hope you heal smoothly and rapidly and am glad dh can help!! I found a website that offers a free reusable lymphedema  bracelet -- http://www.lymphedema.com/alertband.htm -- I sent for one and got it in about a week and wore it when I went in for my heart cath.  Everyone noticed it right away so that was encouraging. I know I should wear something all the time (I'm allergic to penicillin, too) but the normal medic alert bracelets are so clunky and the "pretty" ones, I'm afraid, look too much like regular jewelry and might not get attention, so I've been dragging my feet. Definitely a good idea, though, and I'll address it one of these days.
Posts.Title: A bit of good LE awareness news NatsFan barbe1958

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2010 06:58AM NatureGrrl wrote: My port is also very visible.  However, after a few weeks of having it put in, I had no pain from it, and it's placed where bra straps, etc., aren't an issue.  Do mention it to your surgeon.  I remember a women in my oncologist's office who had a port and she had pain for a couple of months, but it went away.  So it's probably just be a matter of waiting a bit more. I do hope you can continue the exercise -- you're right, it's a very important part of your treatment. I did as much as I could but finally abandoned all after my mom died when I was going through radiation -- I was just worn to a nub.  But I know it would have helped me recover better after treatment if I'd been able to keep it up and I always regretted that I couldn't do better. I really believe your port pain will get better -- good luck, and a warm hug!
Posts.Title: Port Blues - Exercise? anonymice anonymice

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2010 01:59PM NatureGrrl wrote: I'm sure  your post will put a lot of women's minds at ease!  However, some of your cautions are going to disagree with what other people's drs. tell them and it's worth noting that not everyone will get the exact same list of recommendations, and I thought it important to mention this in case others get worried by your post and their recommendations not being the same. This is what my radiation oncologist  recommended, and it worked great for me:  I used aloe vera gel (Jason's, 98% aloe vera) every night, and shea butter (or sometimes aquaphor, but mostly shea butter) on top of that to help seal in moisture.  I had no problems.  It washed off easily in the shower the next morning, and I had no blisters, peeling, etc.  throughout my 38 treatments.  My skin did turn pink/red but was almost completely normal within a few weeks after treatment ended.  They recommended the shea butter/Aquaphor/even Vasoline as an important part of keeping as much moisture in as possible. When I showered I only used soap on my hand to wash that breast and underarm.  No scrubbing needed to remove any "stuff" from the previous night's application. It does pay to avoid anything with alcohol very high up in the ingredient list as it can lead to drier skin.  I also wore no bra or cami for the 2 months, only loose turtlenecks, and I found this much more comfortable than having fabric rubbing tightly against my skin, but this will vary a lot by person.  My skin is much more sensitive to tighter fitting clothes (like camis and bras) than it is to being touched by itself so I wasn't about to wear anything that would aggravate it more. So just keep in mind on some of those details, not to be alarmed if you get a different recommendation from their dr.  than what is listed.  Bottom line:  If in doubt, ask your rad. oncologist or tech team.  Oh, our waiting room always had a jigsaw puzzle going on a gib table, it was the first time I'd seen anything like that in a dr. office and it was lots of fun -- a good ice breaker and something to do if you had to wait (I usually didn't).
Posts.Title: Introduction to Zapland or My First Real Rads 3monstmama 3monstmama

Posts.Content: May 9, 2009 05:56AM NatureGrrl wrote: I just found this thread so I haven't had a chance to read all the posts yet but just wanted to join in briefly. I was diagnosed in early April, first chemo on tax day, second one this past Wed. (a/c, and Neulasta a day later).  Like others I'm finding the second treatment easier, but for me I think a lot of that was expectations and emotions -- I was told not to expect much SE with the first treatment, plus I was only 10 days into my  diagnosis when I had it, so I was overwhelmed and stunned and then got hit by the fatigue much harder than I expected.  So far I'm only 3 days into my 2nd and I know the steroids are part of why I'm not wiped out yet (should hit today or tomorrow!) but I'm also expecting it, paying attention to my body, doing what it asks me to do, and am emotionally more stable.  All that helps.  Naps are good! Bedtime at 6:30 even is good (I've only had to do that once, but I slept 13 hours, sheez!). I'm a generic claritin taker, too, and it does seem to help a lot with the Neulasta aches.  This time will be a better test for me than the first round, since I didn't start taking it until mid-way through the ache cycle. Haven't had any nausea of note (knock on wood!!!!) but I have ativan and Zofran ODT for when I might... and when my stomach nudges me I pop a  half a Tums.  So far, so good on that. Alaina, I don't know you at all, but a huge hug to you! your  post was terrific!  and hugs to all you wonderful, courageous, inspiring women!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo April 2009 tulipbebe MissouriCatLady

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2010 09:37AM NatureGrrl wrote: I agree, consult your dr. -- there are a lot of things that could be at work causing your symptoms, including any drugs you might be taking, high or low bp (also a possible cause of "blacking out"), compromised immune system, etc. etc.   Your dr. will be able to help you find out what's going on and help you make adjustments, if needed.  For now, if you make sure you get up slowly and give your body a few seconds when you stand up, that might help with the "blacking out" feeling.   Please take good and gentle care...
Posts.Title: Symptoms after treatment has ended gfrey NatureGrrl

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2010 04:08PM NatureGrrl wrote: I hope you don't mind my posting here... but I thought perhaps sharing this would let you know you aren't completely forgotten.  I saw this thread a few days ago and was going to write to someone on the local paper that I know personally to remind her to please discuss stage IV, along with other information about bc that tends to get set aside, because I knew they were doing a series of articles this month... and that same day (Oct 1) the paper came out with a BC supplement.  They're doing stories all month (twice a week) on those who have had bc, but the only one to appear in the supplement was of a woman living with stage IV bc. I thought it was meaningful that they chose to put her story in the supplement and not some bright and happy, we're-all-better-story.  So although it's a small step, at least one paper in one community is acknowledging you.
Posts.Title: Why do I feel we are being overlooked cmhartley blondiex46

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2010 09:20AM NatureGrrl wrote: Ask your radiologist/technicians for their opinion.  There are lots of things that work well.  I was specifically told to avoid: -- anything with alcohol in it (I was surprised to see how many "moisturizing" lotions list alcohol high up in the ingredient list) because it may dry skin.  -- putting anything on for 3? 5? hours before rad. (sorry, I can't remember whether it was 3 or 5) because that can exacerbate the effects of rad. My radiation oncologist recommended aloe vera, straight from the plant (great for those of you in the Southwest -- she suggested just breaking off pieces and keeping them in a baggy in the freezer, then smearing the goo on daily) or 98% or more aloe vera gel, plus anything that would help seal moisture in -- Aquaphor, shea butter, even vasoline.  So I used aloe vera, let it dry, then put on shea butter (most of the time) or Aquaphor. For what it's worth, I had no blistering or peeling, but whether that was because of what I used or just my luck, I can't say. I didn't find radiation to be bad at all.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Bag Balm vs / Aloe/creams RegulJ 3monstmama

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2010 09:50AM NatureGrrl wrote: I went braless but otherwise wore my normal clothes.  I wouldn't personally be comfortable with anything with spandex because it tends to cling/rub too much -- mostly I wore turtlenecks that were cotton and model, nothing snug.  Silk would be great, too.  Watch out for seams that might hit a sore spot.  I put aloe vera gel (98%) on my breast every night, then followed it with a slathering of Aquaphor or shea butter.  I got red-skinned but never had any blistering or peeling.  I had 38 treatments. I don't know if my moisturizing campaign helped or if I wouldn't have blistered anyway, but it certainly didn't hurt! Radiation is different for everyone but most get through it pretty well.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: what does the stylish rad patient wear under her shirt? 3monstmama InMontreal

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2010 06:11PM NatureGrrl wrote: Hattie, you can tell us -- believe me, we understand!  I was so sick of pink right after I was dx, I started a thread about "help me explain not embracing the pink" -- you might find some comfort in some of the responses, I know I did!  The support I got was overwhelming. What I'd like to know is what can we do about the Big Pink?  So many of us are obviously sick of the pink, sick of the abuse of bc as a marketing tool, a game, an insensitive event ("Bras across the Wabash" -- a string of donated bras across the Wabash River pedestrian bridge -- is one of the worst I've heard of locally) -- what can we do, especially since the Pink Month is sponsored by corporations, including some drug companies. All I've figured out in my own little corner is to post a "Breast Cancer EDUCATION Month" thought for the day.  I don't reach many but the facts and thoughts that I've shared have gotten some good responses and show that at least for a couple of people, they see something they didn't see before.  But I'd like find a bigger solution.
Posts.Title: "Pink Ribbon Fatigue" - New York Times article 33skidoo NatureGrrl

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 01:08AM - edited Mar 8, 2011 01:10AM by NatureGrrl Meg. I'm prone to anxiety as well, although I've noticed as I've gotten older and learned more about myself and found ways to cope with things, it's gotten quite a bit less frequent and severe.  Coping with anxiety is hard, and everyone is different and has to find what works for them, but here are some things that have helped me: 1.  meditation.  I'm not good at it, and I don't practice as regularly as I'd like, but it helps, even in small doses or emergency situations (like an anxiety attack when I'm waiting for my mammogram results).  There are many different ways -- I like visualization, and TM, the best, but again, it's what works for the individual.  Breathing exercises help me, too.  If you're interested, look for the "Relaxation/ Meditation CD you'd recommend?" thread in the "recommend your resources" forum.  There are several good ideas there. (edited to add, link doesn't work but it should be easy to find the thread). 2.  I ask myself, what do I know right now?  and what can I do to make this better, right now?    I answer those questions.  That brings me more clearly into the moment, instead of projecting ahead. 3.  Once I've figured out what I know and what I can do -- I act. I do what I can and let the rest go. If I can't do anything right now (for example, unless it's an emergency, I can't call the dr. on a weekend), then I've done all I can do and I have to let it go.  Letting go can be hard, but for me, I've found that if I even have the intent to try to let something go, that gets me started on the path, and before I know it, I've actually moved on.  4. I call a close friend and share what I'm going through.  Sometimes the process of getting something said out loud starts to lessen its power over me.  If a friend isn't available, in many communities there are 24-hour crisis hotlines.  5.  I eat something healthy, like an apple.  I know it sounds simple and like it won't help, but it does.  Same with going for a walk or listening to music or watching a comedy or whatever I find soothing.  6.  Also, I try to get enough rest!  My mind can't cope with things nearly as well if I'm not rested. 7.  Before it happens again, I make a list of things I can do to calm myself when it does happen.  Then I have something concrete in front of me when I need it and can't think as clearly, and I can pull out my list and use it. 8.  I've seen a therapist.  Professional guidance is very helpful.  9.  Last, but maybe not least:  I still keep some ativan on hand, small dose.  I don't like using drugs if I can  help it, but I've also come to respect that they can really help.   I was having some serious anxiety last fall over a situation and was getting overwhelmed and finally took an ativan a couple of different times to help me through it.  And, if anxiety is an ongoing issue, I wouldn't hesitate to talk to my dr. about it and maybe go on a daily med for awhile -- I've done that in the past (about 10 years ago, and also when I was going through treatment) and it's always helped ease the stress, and once I've gotten back on my feet and feel I'm ready, I stop whatever I'm on. I don't know if this is really what you were asking for or if it's of any help, but it's here FWIW.  Please do keep us updated.  Thinking of you!
Posts.Title: Really scared MissMeg MissMeg

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 12:08PM NatureGrrl wrote: I agree with lago's advice... soap can be really harsh, as can anything with alcohol in it. I use glycerin soaps, and I use hair conditioner on my skin a lot, a quick coating and rinse right before I get out of the shower.  Look for healing lotions and oils (I like Melaluca products, but use what works for you).  Also, ask your dr. if it's ok to take vitamin supplements. I take 800 iu's of vitamin E daily -- it helped a lot with the cracking (more on my fingers than my feet, but still a big help).  My fingers were extremely painfully cracked but once I got back on the vit. E they were fine. Drink lots of water.  Winter heat/dry air doesn't help, either.  I can't think of anything else but others will chime in with good ideas.  Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Dry Skin Advice Smile_On polamom

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2010 01:02AM NatureGrrl wrote: Absolutely not a problem to miss a day.  My treatments started before the holidays, so I missed Christmas and New Year's days automatically, and then missed a couple of other days at other times due to bad roads.  For me, they just tacked on the missed days to the ends of my treatments.  I had 38 treatments total. You might ask your radiation oncologist about the questions you have about people getting similar treatments.  I think the every day thing is standard partly because it's easier on people to get less strong treatments more often than stronger treatments farther apart.  Within that, I'm guessing dosage, etc., may vary quite a bit.  I had most of my treatments on the entire breast but the last 5 treatments were targeted to where my lump had been.  There's room for a lot of variation within the every day program. Meanwhile, plan on going to your work meeting!  And good luck!
Posts.Title: Can you/did you ever miss a day? Raili Raili

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2010 11:05PM NatureGrrl wrote: I had A/C, taxol, herceptin... last chemo was about 7 months.  I've been told fatigue is normal for a year or more, but you should see improvement, although radiation will take a little out of you, but in my experience, it's not anywhere nearly as overwhelming as chemo. Nerve regrowth is very slow, so it's a long slow process to get over neuropathy.  My fingers have been normal for a couple of months or more, and my feet/toes are almost there.  If you progress like me you'll see gradual but steady improvement. As mentioned, some people don't ever recover fully, but many do or at least see improvement. SE's from radiation include fatigue and possible skin reactions.  Find out what your radiation oncologist/techs suggest to put on your skin. I used 98% aloe vera gel every night, and put shea butter or Aquaphor on top of that to seal in moisture, and only had skin redness -- no burning or blistering.  But everyone reacts differently, and your ability to tan/burn plays no role here (or so I've been told). I had some SE's after chemo -- aches and pains.  They went away within a few months.  I was told the steriods I was taking during chemo probably masked the pains until I was done with it.  Not sure that makes complete sense to me :) but it's one explanation. Also, chemo can cause damage to other parts of your body. I've had numerous extra blood tests since I finished all treatments to check various functions and rule out other causes of fatigue. In my case, I've had minor heart damage and I have mild hypothyroidism now. I'm on meds for the first (and hoping that time heals the damage at least some) and waiting to see my doc about the second.  So don't be surprised if other things crop up that weren't problems before.  Keep your doctors informed of any symptoms.  The problems I'm having, though, are minor and mild compared to not having my cancer treated! And one thing that I don't see mentioned often as an SE:  emotional impacts.  I didn't have time/energy to really digest that I even had cancer and what all that meant until I was done with treatment, and then I went through some depression/grief/etc., but by that time I was able to process it fairly quickly.  Some people also experience a feeling of abandonment after chemo ends because they aren't getting the regular support of the oncology staff (but daily radiation made up for that in my case!).  And, the really good news (to me, at least!) was that I finally got my mojo back!!  I feel like my old self, but much better, emotionally -- more grounded, happier, stronger, experiencing joy, etc.  Don't be surprised if you go through some emotional SE's as well. Best of luck through rads.  You've got the worst behind you!  Hang in there -- things will get  better!
Posts.Title: Side effects after chemo is over JudyM Texas357

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2010 10:08PM NatureGrrl wrote: Thanks, Athena. Well said.    It's time we all unite.
Posts.Title: "Pink Ribbon Fatigue" - New York Times article 33skidoo NatureGrrl

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2010 01:46AM NatureGrrl wrote: I had A/C and 12 weeks of Taxol, along with 6 months of Herceptin.   My onc. was much more concerned about the potential heart damage from Herceptin than Adriamycin.  I had a mugascan every 3 months to monitor my heart.  I did have enough of a decline that he pulled me off the Herceptin. Future problems are possible from the Adriamycin, but unlikely.   I had a heart cath after treatment to do a more thorough check of my heart.  The cardiologist said I have "minor impairment" -- he didn't like the word "damage."  But I'm fine.  I can do whatever I want.  I'm exercising regularly and building myself back up. I'm not worried about future heart problems.  If they come, they come, but cancer is a horrible disease and I don't want it back, ever.   I'm doing everything I can to stay healthy and strong and keep the cancer at bay. I used all the tools in my arsenal to beat the cancer.  You never know what microscopic cancer cells may be floating around and the chemo can help.  It wasn't any fun and it wore me down to a nub but in the overall scheme of things, that time was just a blip on my radar.  If you're healthy and in good shape, you have a head start if you do go into chemo.  Keep up your exercise, etc., as best as you can and it'll pay off afterwards in your body's ability to recover.  You won't destroy your body with chemo -- you may set it back some, but you'll rebound. Having said all that... it is a personal decision and you may chose to skip chemo.  Talk with your dr., the nurses, get a second opinion... whatever helps set your mind at ease and helps you make a decision that you feel is best for you.  Good luck.  We're all here for you any time.
Posts.Title: Anyone taking Adriamycin for Chemo Lovelyface Lovelyface

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2011 09:17AM NatureGrrl wrote: Meg, I don't have information for you, just some support:  although it's hard (believe me, I know!) try not to jump to conclusions. I know you're scared and that's really normal... you're certainly in the right place for people understanding that fear. As soon as possible, call your dr. and schedule an appointment.  Knowing is better than not-knowing, and from what you say, it sounds really likely this can be the neurofibromatosis, although I know nothing about that condition -- I'm just basing this on what you said in your post. To the best of my knowledge, cancer doesn't present with cold symptoms, so I wouldn't read much into that. Take some deep breathes.  We all live with that fear (I have wrist problems and after I got the x-ray, the first thing I asked was if the x-ray showed cancer) (the answer was no) and it's hard not to jump to conclusions, but try not to borrow trouble.  Do things to help you relax, try to get some extra rest, eat well, and find something to make yourself laugh (I turn to baby-laughing videos on youtube at times like this -- they always make me smile!).  Let your dr. know ASAP so you can get this dx and moved on with the (very long!) rest of your life.  Warm hugs and best of luck.
Posts.Title: Really scared MissMeg MissMeg

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2009 07:28AM NatureGrrl wrote: I had two wires placed with the clip in the middle. (the wires kind of marked the outer edges of the lump, or rather, the lump as it was before chemo). The radiologist and surgeon wanted to make sure the entire original lump area was excised, thus the double wires.  The procedure for me was almost pain-free.  This was 2 weeks ago. They took the lump (which my surgeon described as "large" and my oncologist called "relatively small."  Figure that one out!  It was 2-3  cm.) and under my arm, a lymph node and some surrounding tissue which ended up containing 14 lymph nodes (!). If there weren't a scar/incision there, I wouldn't be able to tell they took anything out of my breast, and most people assured me that the body has a way of "filling in" what's taken anyway.  Oddly, and to my surprise, I was very calm for my lumpectomy, even knowing that I still might come out of it needing a mastectomy (not the case, however).  I found the surgery & recovery have been pretty darn easy.  But after 6 months of miserable chemo I guess a little cutting didn't seem so bad!    It's natural to be nervous, especially if you haven't had surgery before, but it really will be ok -- it's one of those things where the anticipation is definitely the worst part.  Hang in there -- sending hugs -- Carol
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy Surgery Question VegasKat vtmom

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2011 05:21PM NatureGrrl wrote: Many of us did all the right things and still got BC.  It sucks, and it lends a lot of credence to the theory that there are multiple causes for what are really multiple kinds of BC. I didn't have the same chemo but I did chemo, lumpectomy, rads... I was told I could do chemo first or mastectomy first, that my prognosis would be the same either way.  I fully expected to have a mast. anyway but chose chemo first because I felt I could deal with it better (after the shock of dx) than surgery.  Turns out, after I was done with chemo they couldn't find any traces of chemo in an MRI and then later in the margins of my lump or in the lump itself.  I will say, my surgeon still thought I should do a mast. but was willing to do the lump. instead.  Kind of a long story but to his credit, he was really glad I followed my gut on that one.  If you have questions or want more of my story please feel free to PM me.  Cancer sucks but you can do it.  We're all here to help.  Best of luck.

Posts.Title: And I thought I was doing good - Ha! LRM216 LRM216

Posts.Content: May 12, 2009 09:00AM NatureGrrl wrote: Linda, I'm having a/c every 3 weeks; just had my second one last Wed.  Because the WBC count drop is common after a/c (or so I understand), I get a Neulasta shot the day after my treatment to stimulate WBC production.  My oncologist takes my labs (blood) every week so the first week after my first treatment I, too, was told I was neutropenic. My WBC was just over 1.  I was also told this was normal, to be expected, and not to worry -- the Neulasta would kick in and do its job,  It did.  2 weeks after treatment, my WBC was well back within the normal range.  Of course I take precautions not to pick up infections while my WBC is low (wash my hands a lot, stay away from big crowds, etc.) (like I had the energy to be around crowds anyway!) :)  And I didn't have the complications you're having with cellulitis, so my situation isn't the same... but I hope my WBC experience at least lets you know your body is responding to the chemo in a normal way.  I hope they get everything under control for you -- none of this is any fun and you're getting hit with extra stuff! One advantage to having a/c every three weeks, at least to my mind:  I got a nice rebound after that first week of being wiped out, and felt halfway human again for several days (my cycle was split about 50/50: 10 days of fatigue, 10 of real energy) before getting zapped again.   I really took advantage of that 10 days of energy.  It makes the fatigue days more bearable to know that there is some sort of recovery, even if temp.  I'm on the upward swing of my second cycle; fatigue today is a tiny bit less than yesterday, so I'm looking forward to the weekend.  For me, at least, even a moment of feeling human and normal makes the rest of it a lot more bearable. FWIW, even though my first treatment went OK, I was pretty anxious over the second, but it's actually turned out to be a bit easier -- not less fatigue or anything, but I knew what to expect and have been listening to my body better and overall I've found it less stressfull and easier to roll with the punches.  I hope you have the same experience!  Hang in there!
Posts.Title: And I thought I was doing good - Ha! LRM216 LRM216

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2010 09:39AM NatureGrrl wrote: I had (have) neuropathy from Taxol.  It wasn't really bad -- I could still knit and type just fine -- my toes bothered me more than my fingers.  Going barefoot was somewhat painful.  I'm almost 6 months away from my last Taxol and the neuropathy is slowly getting better.  I don't notice it in my fingers any more and only in a few of my toes.  It's not painful, just somewhat distracting, at this point.  Nerve regrowth is very slow but for most it does happen!  And as mentioned already, it might not affect you, so try not to get too worried.  I don't think what you're experiencing so far is indicative of neuropathy.  Pay attention to your body and ask your dr. about anything that concerns you, and try not to anticipate problems before they arrive -- easier said than done, I know. My NP suggested vit.B6 supplements to help prevent/delay neuropathy, and I have been taking it religiously twice a day since I started chemo.   Did it help?  There's no way to know for sure, but it didn't hurt.  I'm also still taking Neurotin, which helps minimize the symptoms of neuropathy (but doesn't cure it or stop it) -- I still have symptoms but when I stopped taking it the symptoms were worse so I decided to keep taking it until they go away or are almost gone.  So even if you get neuropathy keep in mind that there's a med out there to help. Bottom line, even if you get some neuropathy, for most people it's managable and goes away after chemo stops.  Best of luck!
Posts.Title: Peripheral Neuropathy and Taxotere faithfulc JudyM

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2010 03:18AM NatureGrrl wrote: lago, for what it's worth, I don't have LE at all (yet) (knock on wood) but I've had ongoing concerns about it.  In the middle of a bout of concern I was seeing my radiation oncologist -- she was extremely receptive to listening to me and although she was very reassuring, she also felt it would help me a lot to see an LE therapist.  It was a one-hour education session and it was so extremely helpful, even for someone only with concerns.  I've learned a lot on these boards and from LE websites but there's nothing like going to an expert.  It gave me a lot of peace of mind and answered questions I didn't know I had :)   And now if I do have issues, questions, I can go straight to her (I already called her about joining a gym, for example).    Just my 2 cents. Glad you're doing well.  I'm going to go pump some light weights myself :)
Posts.Title: I'm so confused | Sleeve or no sleeve | early LE lago lago

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2010 12:14PM - edited Jul 13, 2010 12:48PM by NatureGrrl First step:  deep breaths, slowly...  now.... it's hard and we've been there -- but you can do this.  So far your news has all been good, and the rest is unknown, and the unknown is always the hardest part to deal with. I've also had a lumpectomy and some of the scar tissue does feel like lumps,  I had to get used to the changed feel of what's normal in that breast.  And, I have an area of my breast than sinks in; it's where all that tissue (the lump) was removed. But having said that -- I would (and do) call my dr. with any concerns.  If you find your dr. unresponsive, find another dr.  During treatment, I used to call my oncologist a couple of times a week and felt bad about it until the nurses said that they have people that call several times a DAY, and that I should always err on the side of caution. I wouldn't wait three months to find out about that new lump, either, but having said that, how big is the new lump?   I had some "spots" on my lung that were monitored for almost a year and got very frustrated being told I had to wait yet another 3 months after every CTscan -- but they were too small to biopsy.  (They finally vanished).  I don't know if that could be the case here or not, if that lump is too small to otherwise test, but a second opinion never hurts, especially if it gives you peace of mind.  Second, on seeing therapists/counselors:  three weeks is a very short time to have been seeing someone.  You've been going through some significant trauma and still have some unknowns over your head.  That's going to bring up a whole variety of emotions that could include fear, sadness, etc... all normal and all take time to process.  When you have health issues like this another thing that's hard is that there is so much that you can't control -- so what helped me was controlling the pieces I could.  You'll have to figure out what that is for you; just remember that your emotions are one of the things you only have partial control over, and it's ok to feel them; in fact, it helps to allow them to be there so that you can better let go of them.  If that makes any sense!  As mentioned, meds aren't a bad idea, either, if you start feeling too overwhelmed.  You and your therapist and dr. can decide. Finally, and this is the hardest part about waiting, but try to focus on what you know and what you can do, and try not to let your imagination run wild with what might be.  Like I said, that's really hard, but don't let the joy of today be overshadowed by the "maybes" of tomorrow any more than you can help. I know how scary this is. I walked around for 3 months with a lump in my breast, convinced I was going to die because I had no insurance and if it was cancer no one would treat me.  I finally realized that no matter what, knowing was better than the way I was living.  Take action, do what you can, find things that calm you, hug everyone who'll let you :), take deep breaths, try to eat right and sleep enough, and remember, no matter what, you've found the right place for support and comfort, and you can do this.  You're still strong.  Feeling all those icky emotions doesn't make you less strong; but it's just part of life.  Warm hug...

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2010 08:02AM NatureGrrl wrote: I finished rads in Feb. and for me it took months before I could get through a day without a long nap...  no interest in sex but no man in my life so in a way it doesn't matter, but I do miss having a sex drive (and a man in my life, for that matter)   I'm on Arimidex, not T., I do have some joint aches and pains but they come and go and with the addition of some supplements and exercise, they're very managable.   Still, I felt like crap for what felt like a very long time. But -- I did slowly see progress in my energy and well-being.  The biggest thing for me in healing from all the treatment is that my joy came back, and I'm so grateful.  I still have days where I want to cry and/or have absolutely no energy, but overall I'm going in the right direction... I also have days where I feel pretty darn good (at least until I start to crash late afternoon/early evening!).  So... yes, I know exactly how you feel.  But if it helps, things do get better.  Big hug.

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 01:47AM NatureGrrl wrote: Yes, be a sponge, write everything down, have a second set of ears (sometimes you won't hear the same things or you'll miss things).  But also ask questions, and don't let go of the questions until you're clear that you have the information you're asking for. Questions to ask will depend on what you already know and what you hear.... do you have any details yet at all?  If not -- find out the type of cancer (DCIS, IBC, IDC, ILC), grade (1, 2, 3), hormone receptor status (HER, ER, PR plus or minus), and stage (I, II, III, IV, often with an a, b, c division at each stage).  What are your treatment options, how many treatments, how long do the various infusions. radiations, etc., last, what are expected side effects, lumpectomy or mastectomy or no surgery; if mastectomy, reconstruction options... the list can go on and on but until you have some specifics it's hard to narrow it down.  After my initial meeting with my oncologist I came away with a treatment plan but met with him again to go over questions that came up after I saw him. Do research on your own, as well, if you like, and don't be afraid to take time to assimilate all the information before you make a decision.  Trust your gut.  You'll do the right thing for you. Take care, good luck, and a warm hug!
Posts.Title: 1st appt w/oncologist, what to ask and expect? punkyandjohnnasmom vivirasselena

Posts.Title: Just have a quick question Lynn97 Lynn97

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 10:07AM NatureGrrl wrote: I don't know that I can be much help except to say your GP should be able to push for an appointment for you.  I know the first mammogram I had after finding my lump, the radiologist told me it would be "weeks" before I could get a biopsy  because they were too booked up, although she was sure I had cancer; I went upstairs to my mother's oncologist's office and within hours had an appointment for a biopsy a few days later (with the same radiologist who told me they had nothing available).  Ask your GP if s/he will intercede on your behalf. Your GP can possibly aspirate it, and as awful as it sounds, I had a lump (cyst) aspirated once and it was literally just a very mild pinprick and not painful.  So that might be another option to get you more information quickly.  It's not a biopsy but depending on what they pull with the needle at least you're armed with more information Also -- be a squeaky wheel.  Be kind and polite but persistant in trying to get an appointment.  And, don't panic... it's hard not to, I know, but take some deep breaths and don't let your mind wander too far until you actually know what you're dealing with.  Others will probably have some more helpful suggestions. Best of luck and a warm hug.
Posts.Title: How do you get a specialist to take you seriously? FlyingSolo FlyingSolo

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 09:58AM NatureGrrl wrote: Lynn, my first reaction is, don't put up with that. He sounds (I'm being harsh and judgemental, but...) arrogant and rude.  I would take my complaints about him to my GP (be specific and clear and not overly emotional when you relay the information) and ask for another referal.  My first radiologist really had a god complex, was very rude and thoughtless and hurtful (all the time commending herself on her ability to be sensitive!  My jaw dropped, really!) and when I told my oncologist about all the radiologist said to me and how she treated me, he immediately got me to another one.  On the other hand, some drs. do change if they realize what they're doing. Like any of us they get in a rush and distracted.  A friend had a bad experience with her mother's dr trying to rush through an appointment, not answering or ignoring questions, etc... so in the middle of it my friend got up, moved her chair in front of the door, and sat down again.  The dr. took the hint and immediately became more attentive and spent all the time they needed.  So if you can catch them before they get out the door, I suppose it is possible to get their attention.   Some will respond to the second chance and some won't.  In your case, I'd say find someone else, but I try to keep my friend's experience  in mind when I'm sitting in that little room :)  Best of luck!
Posts.Title: Just have a quick question Lynn97 Lynn97

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2011 11:53AM NatureGrrl wrote: You aren't alone.  I was told to expect to take 1-3 years after treatment before I started feeling normal energy again -- it's just been a year and I'd say I'm getting there.  I did see progress over the last year, just not as fast as I wanted, but seeing progress at all kept me believing that I would get better.  Treatment is tough on your entire system, physically, emotionally, on every level possible.  Are you still getting your blood levels checked?  If not you might want to see if you can get your WBC and other immune system counts checked to see if you're low.  That would certainly impact your getting colds and recovery from them.  Physical activity has helped me a lot, too, although I sometimes have trouble staying motivated; and just generally taking extra gentle care (resting as needed, getting lots of sleep, eating healthy, drinking lots of water, and meditation) has helped as well.  Not every day is full of energy yet but I have more of them than tired days and I completely enjoy the energetic ones!  Hang in there...

My best to you and your family as you go through this part of your mother's journey with her.  Warm hugs.
Posts.Title: Lung Dropped Down?!?! BrokenHeart lwd

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2010 08:22AM NatureGrrl wrote: I don't know anything about intramammary lymph nodes so I did a quick search myself and found this as a part of a research study: "Intramammary lymph nodes (IMLNs) are not uncommon, and are likely to be more frequently identified with the wider use of mammography and breast ultrasound."  From that and from other things I read, it doesn't sound like an imln is anything in and of itself to be concerned about and that most don't lead to cancer. But you're right, much of what's talked about is the involvement of imln's in/with cancer, so I can see why that alarmed you.  And I can understand why your friend's story also alarms you, but keep in mind that's her story and that doesn't mean it'll be yours.   However -- you are concerned, and concerns warrant a second opinion.  So don't hesitate to see another physician.  I'm a big believer in following my instincts and if mine were telling me to get another opinion, I would.  At the very worst, it'll mean they catch something earlier than they would have otherwise; at the best, it'll give you peace of mind.   Good luck to you.

My oncologist said no for the 3-4 days following chemo and only wine or beer.   I don't know if that was because the alcohol can interfere with some chemos or if it was to help my liver not go through more stress.   In any event, it wasn't a problem as I had little desire to drink.  Best of luck to you.

Posts.Title: What was your favorite head covering through chemo? BooBee Brendatrue

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2010 06:31PM NatureGrrl wrote: I didn't have insurance, either.  Very scary.  My oncologist said he didn't care, he would get me through it (and you have no idea how much that meant to me -- I figured if I didn't have insurance, no one would treat me and I'd die.  One hell of a thought to live with for 3 months).  Fortunately, instead of racking up thousands of dollars of debt, I found out about a fast-track Medicaid program for people with breast and cervical cancer through the state that got me on Medicaid in just a few weeks (instead of the months Medicaid usually takes).  See if that program exists in FL; specifically ask about the fast-track option.  My oncologist's insurance person didn't know about it; I found out about it through our local YWCA and their breast cancer program; I think every state has the bc program but not every state has the fast-track option.  Medicaid programs can vary some state to state.  For example, in IN breast cancer treatment isn't considered life-long (as it is where Bren lives).  I have to go through a review every year, but since I'm getting a hormone-blocking drug I'm still being treated so my insurance will continue until I can find a job with coverage. Check more into your own insurance program, too.  With group coverage they can't deny you coverage but they can impose a waiting period so you might want to find out about any thing like that so you won't be blindsided later.  I know you both already feel overwhelmed and you don't need more surprises than you're already getting. I agree, don't wait to start setting up appointments and gathering information.  Knowledge is power, and you'll feel like you're doing something because you will be doing something.  I found it helped me a lot to take control where ever I could, rather than letting the cancer control everything.  I started treatment before I found out if I would have insurance; you may be able to do that, too.  I don't understand why they can't tell you more after her biopsy -- after mine, I was able to find out type, grade, stage, etc etc., all the details, although some took a few days longer to get back than others -- you might have to ask more specific questions to get more answers?  Don't know, but I do know it doesn't hurt to ask.  After a biopsy you'd think they'd have what they need but I certainly don't know about all biopsies, just mine. Best wishes and a warm hug to you both.
Posts.Title: PLEASE HELP! Medvetz63 dlb823

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2010 08:44PM NatureGrrl wrote: I'm not in your "category" so my experiences don't count -- however, I will say, if you do take Neulasta -- thanks to the women on this board I was told to try taking generic Claritin (not Claritin-D) for the duration of my Neulasta shots (12 weeks for me, one shot every 3 weeks).  After my first Neulasta I hadn't heard of that and I was so achy I could barely walk.  Heard about the Claritin solution, made sure my oncologist OK'd it ("it can't hurt") and all my aches disappeared and I had no SE's from it from there forward. Do ask your oncologist if it's OK if you decide to try it  (the generic Claritin). My WBC plummeted, even with Neulasta, but again, I'm not in your category, so I really can't compare my situation with yours. I  do know I prefered dealing with Neulasta to coming down with an illness that would put me in the hospital or keep me from continuing treatment -- but again, my situation is not the same as yours.   There are no clear answers to most of this, as you're realizing :)  Gather information, let it sink it, then listen to your gut and go with it. Steroids are optional.  Everything is optional.  Steroids are used to combat nausea.  For me, I'd way rather deal with the steroid SE's (short-lived and aggravating, but short-lived) than throw up.  Even with steroids and other meds I had nausea, but I never came close to throwing up.  Not everyone feels that way about it, though. Discuss it with your dr. and decide for yourself.  Some women are able to at least reduce their steroids and therefore have less SE's. I know it's overwhelming but you have to be your own advocate -- so bug your dr. with all your questions.   Don't let him/her treat you like a drive-by patient -- and if he is, find someone else.  This is your health and life and deserves to be treated seriously. Age is relative.  To me, 42 is young. Pretty darn young, actually.   I'm 58. And BTW, I'm not old!  :)  It's relative.  That may be why your dr. keeps saying that.    Good luck, big hugs, and hang in there.
